description: From Middle English enclinen, from Old French encliner (modern incliner), from Latin inclīnō (“incline, tilt”), from in- + clīnō (compare -cline), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱley- (English lean).

examples: To reach the building, we had to climb a steep incline.

entries.meaning: A portal of a subway tunnel.

verbs.description: incline (third-person singular simple present inclines, present participle inclining, simple past and past participle inclined)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bend or move (something) out of a given plane or direction, often the horizontal or vertical.
examples: He had to incline his body against the gusts to avoid being blown down in the storm.
The people following the coffin inclined their heads in grief.
Over the centuries the wind made the walls of the farmhouse incline.

entries.meaning: (chiefly intransitive, chiefly passive) To tend to do or believe something, or move or be moved in a certain direction, away from a point of view, attitude, etc.
examples: He inclines to believe anything he reads in the newspapers.
I'm inclined to give up smoking after hearing of the risks to my health.
